G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: The Court retains continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting-time orders for the Children. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 259–60 (2001).

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 259–60 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: The Court retains continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting-time orders for the Children. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 259–60 (2001).
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the court’s *continuing jurisdiction* over custody and parenting‑time orders under G.L. c. 208, § 28. Rosenthal v. Maney applies § 28’s *substantive standard* for when a prior custody judgment may be modified (material and substantial change in circumstances) and critiques a temporary custody change under § 28A, but it does not discuss or ground its analysis in the concept of ongoing or continuing jurisdiction to modify such orders. The only jurisdictional discussion concerns removal under § 30 and the effect of later statutes, not the court’s retention of jurisdiction over custody and parenting time generally.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10.proposition: At the time the 2020 Custody Order entered, the Court determined that the schedule set forth therein was in the best interests of the Children, consistent with G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 10, as interpreted by cases such as Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003), and Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985).

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: At the time the 2020 Custody Order entered, the Court determined that the schedule set forth therein was in the best interests of the Children, consistent with G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 10, as interpreted by cases such as Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003), and Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that custody determinations for nonmarital children under G.L. c. 209C, § 10 are governed by the ‘best interests of the child’ standard, and it traces that standard to prior Massachusetts cases, including Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas. It affirms a detailed physical‑custody/visitation schedule expressly because it is in the child’s best interests, thereby providing authority for the general proposition that a custody schedule, when ordered, reflects a judicial determination of the children’s best interests consistent with the governing statutes. Thus, citing Custody of Kali for that generic best‑interests proposition is accurate.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly … as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history…. [T]he ‘best interests’ standard … has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation. See, e.g., … Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: At the time the 2020 Custody Order entered, the Court determined that the schedule set forth therein was in the best interests of the Children, consistent with G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 10, as interpreted by cases such as Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003), and Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985).
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: Yannas concerns (1) an initial custody determination between divorcing parents and (2) a removal request under G.L. c. 208, § 30, applying a "real advantage" best‑interests analysis. It does not interpret or apply G.L. c. 208, § 28 or G.L. c. 209C, § 10, nor does it discuss the type of post‑judgment, 2020 custody order referenced in the proposition. While it does apply a general best‑interests standard, citing it as authority that the 2020 Custody Order was determined to be in the children’s best interests under §§ 28 and 10 is inaccurate.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that “[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.” The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these “best interests” are to be determined.

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 899–900 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Since entry of the 2020 Custody Order, there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances affecting the Children and the parenting schedule, warranting modification of the order pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and related case law. See, e.g., Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 840–41; Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 899–900 (1981).
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the criteria and findings required for an initial custody determination (or a rehearing of that determination), focusing on the child’s best interests and rejecting custody as punishment for a parent’s misconduct. It does not address modification standards, material or substantial change in circumstances, or the statutory framework under G.L. c. 208, § 28 or G.L. c. 209C, § 20. Thus it does not support the specific proposition about a substantial and material change justifying modification of an existing custody order.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865, 871–73 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: This change in Father’s employment schedule is substantial and permanent or indefinite, not temporary, and directly interferes with his ability to exercise overnight parenting time in a manner that is safe, consistent, and in the Children’s best interests. See Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. at 259–61; Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865, 871–73 (2006).
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: Pizzino v. Miller concerns a custodial parent's request to remove children from Massachusetts and applies the Yannas ‘real advantage’ removal framework. It does not address modification of parenting time based on a parent's changed employment schedule, nor does it analyze whether a change is substantial, permanent/indefinite versus temporary, or its impact on the safety or consistency of overnight parenting time. The case is about relocation/removal standards and the effect of a custodial parent’s remarriage, so citing it for the proposition about a father’s work-schedule change interfering with overnight parenting time is not accurate authority.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “Since 1985, we have applied the criteria of the Yannas decision. Stated succinctly, we look first at the reasons underlying the desire of the parent with physical custody (usually the mother) to move. ‘[T]he first consideration is whether there is a good reason for the move, a “real advantage.”’ … Should it be found that there is a genuine, recognizable advantage to the custodial parent from the move, the inquiry then turns to whether the move is consistent with the children’s best interests.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–05 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: The pattern of Father’s last‑minute drop‑offs, inconsistent availability, and reliance on a third party for supervision during his scheduled overnights creates instability, disrupts the Children’s routines, and undermines the predictability and structure that are essential to their well‑being. See Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–05 (1981) (stability and continuity are important factors in custody determinations).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The case does not discuss last‑minute drop‑offs or reliance on third parties, but it is cited only for the narrower, parenthetical point that stability and continuity are important factors in custody determinations. Rolde expressly emphasizes that children’s strongest bond with a primary caretaker and a custodial arrangement that "minimizes disruption" and "fosters a healthy environment" are critical considerations, reflecting a concern for stability and continuity in the children’s lives. Thus, while the specific factual pattern in the proposition is not in Rolde, the general legal principle about stability and continuity in custody decisions is supported.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: The judge found the wife has been the “primary nurturing parent” and “primary caretaker” and that the children have the “strongest bond” with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.

M.P.M. v. V.M., 72 Mass. App. Ct. 796, 8.proposition: Father’s consistent inability to exercise overnight parenting time as originally ordered, and his shift‑work schedule that is incompatible with regular overnights, constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the 2020 Custody Order. See, e.g., M.P.M. v. V.M., 72 Mass. App. Ct. 796, 800–01 (2008); Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738–39 (1996).
M.P.M. v. V.M., 72 Mass. App. Ct. 796, 8.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses what constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances under G.L. c. 208, § 28, but it does so in the context of alleged maternal neglect and the child’s emotional well‑being, not in relation to a parent’s inability to exercise ordered overnights or work‑schedule incompatibility. The case contains no facts or holding about a parent’s shift work, missed overnights, or scheduling problems constituting a material change. Citing M.P.M. v. V.M. for that specific proposition overstates its relevance and is not accurate authority for that point.
M.P.M. v. V.M., 72 Mass. App. Ct. 796, 8.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a judge of the Probate and Family Court may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ See Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738 (1996) …”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738–39 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Father’s consistent inability to exercise overnight parenting time as originally ordered, and his shift‑work schedule that is incompatible with regular overnights, constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the 2020 Custody Order. See, e.g., M.P.M. v. V.M., 72 Mass. App. Ct. 796, 800–01 (2008); Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738–39 (1996).
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion in Ardizoni v. Raymond does discuss the statutory standard of a ‘material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties’ under G.L. c. 208, § 28, but the only change it identifies and upholds is the mother’s rehabilitation from alcohol and drug dependence. The case does not involve, analyze, or treat a parent’s inability to exercise overnights or an incompatible work schedule as a material change, nor does it connect any access or scheduling issue to the material‑change finding. Citing Ardizoni for the proposition that a father’s inconsistent overnight parenting and shift‑work schedule constitute a material and substantial change misstates the basis of the decision.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: "In allowing the wife’s complaint for modification, the judge cited as a material and substantial change in circumstances, the wife’s ‘great success in overcoming her alcohol and drug dependence.’ … the wife’s progress in this regard, since the divorce decree granting temporary physical custody of the twins to the father, was supported by evidence in the record. Hence, the finding that a material and substantial change in circumstances had occurred was not clearly erroneous."

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 544\u2.proposition: This change is of such a nature that modification of the existing parenting-time schedule is now necessary to serve the best interests of the Children. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 840–41; Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 544–45 (2010).
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 544\u2.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Smith v. McDonald is a concurring opinion focused on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and the mother’s unilateral right to relocate before paternity is established. It does not discuss a material and substantial change of circumstances or when a change would warrant modification of a parenting-time schedule under G.L. c. 208, § 28. Instead, it emphasizes that the judge was not allowed to order the child and mother back to Massachusetts and that the relocation had to be accepted as a given when fashioning custody and visitation, which is the opposite of using the relocation as a basis to modify parenting time to serve the child’s best interests.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 544\u2.relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003).”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (19.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time decision is the best interests of the child. G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 10; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 840; Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (1998).
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the core issue, once parental unfitness is found, as determining what arrangement is in the child’s best interests and treats that as the governing standard under G.L. c. 210, § 3. While this case arises in an adoption/care-and-protection context rather than c. 208 or c. 209C, it clearly reaffirms that the controlling consideration in resolving competing custody/adoption plans is the child’s best interests, which is consistent with the proposition’s statement of Massachusetts law.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (19.relevant_excerpt: Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The “best interests of a child” is a question that presents the trial judge “with a classic example of a discretionary decision.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.proposition: The Children are now school‑aged (8 and 6) and require consistent routines, adequate sleep, safe and appropriate supervision, and a stable home environment. See Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595–96 (1996) (court may consider child’s age, needs, and stability); Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. at 404–05.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the need for explicit findings regarding the impact of domestic violence on the child and the best‑interests analysis, not on the general developmental needs of school‑aged children for routines, sleep, supervision, or a stable home environment. While it notes the child’s age and some aspects of his school performance and relationship with his parents, it does not articulate any general principle that children of a certain age require consistent routines and stability. Thus, it does not meaningfully support the specific proposition for which it is cited, even though it generally concerns best‑interests factors.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.relevant_excerpt: We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below “fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.” … The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother. … It is well documented that witnessing domestic violence, as well as being one of its victims, has a profound impact on children.

Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 61.proposition: Mother has primary physical custody and is consistently available during the evenings and overnight to provide direct, personal care for the Children. Adjusting the parenting schedule so that overnights occur only when Father is actually off work and available will better protect the Children’s physical, emotional, and developmental needs. See Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 619–20 (1986) (court must consider capacity of parent to provide for child’s needs).
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 61.support_reasoning: The case is a care-and-protection termination-type proceeding, not a dispute between parents over scheduling or overnights. While the opinion does state that courts must find parents “currently unfit to care and provide for their children” and base decisions on the children’s best interests, it does not address adjusting parenting time so that overnights occur only when a parent is off work, nor does it discuss a parent’s evening/overnight availability as a factor. The citation is thus too general to support the specific scheduling and primary-physical-custody proposition asserted.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 61.relevant_excerpt: “A decision to remove children permanently from the home of their natural parents must be supported by clear and convincing evidence that the parents are currently unfit to care and provide for their children… Additionally, the personal rights implicated in proceedings of this nature require the judge to exercise the utmost care in deciding custody matters. ‘Such care . . . demands that the judge enter specific and detailed findings demonstrating that close attention has been given the evidence and that the necessity of removing the child[ren] from [their] parents has been persuasively shown.’”
